headline: pressure from people, not job
status:
5 April 2020
"pressure from people, not job"
3.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros:
- salary is satisfactory for fresh grad ($17888)
- work location is next to MTR
- regular working time (8:45-5:33)
- low workload
cons:
- always review your performance even you've done nothing wrong
- have too much to say on your own personal life (e.g. asking your family, status etc)
- everything goes too inefficient
- blame you when you have low workload
- supervisor is too picky
- unclear instruction
- no promotion scheme for small hospital, you need to apply it by yourself
- no bonus 
- NO HOME OFFICE FOR NON-ESSENTIAL STAFF, expose all staff in DANGER!
- If they don't like you, they can do everything to kick you out; but even you are not smart, you can stay long when you got them.
advice_to_mgmt: - please pay more attention to PPE purchasing of clinical staff instead of being too picky

Current Employee

- Salary package similar or better than the government (with allowances)
- Free medical consultations in all public hospitals
cons:
- Stressful work environment (Loads of work but inadequate manpower)
- Expect three mens' workload but with one man's paid 
- Poor planning which leads to poor execution
advice_to_mgmt: Manpower is the greatest resources of a company. You have to seriously review work distributions and to retain talents, or they all flock to the private sector (both clinical and admin) and you left with no one to perform duties to service the public.

headline: HA
pros: Top down management with corporate identity is to be caring for staff. Clinical and non clinical work are challenging. Workplace equity and staff culture are welcoming.
cons: You do not have bonus and profit sharing for the success of the outcome, be it clinical or non clinical. Monetary motivation is non existent.
advice_to_mgmt: Recognize that it is the senior managers duty to provide adequate staffing. Pay attention to workload of staff and be flexible to ask for resources to meet increased workload, uphold standard and care.

headline: HA is Horrible, unless you have only ever known HA.
status:
7 March 2014
Helpful (1)
"HA is Horrible, unless you have only ever known HA."
2.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: Good pay in net terms for Hong Kong and abroad. Residency and Specialisation gets better.
cons: Poor innovation, not accepting of Western-Trainees and ideas, ridiculous hours, no recognition of previous specialisation, xenophobic.
advice_to_mgmt: They need to do what is best for HK and its sick population, not what is politically safe. They need to want to innovate.

headline: Bad Managers
pros: Steady job! Very routine and pays a decent but not a high amount of money. It is also a safe job.
cons:
1. People who obsess about hierarchy and permission and grade levels.
2. I don’t pay you to think. This is what a bad manager says when an employee offers an idea he doesn’t like.
3. Drop everything and DO THIS NOW!Poor managers do it every day, and they never remember the dozen equally critical (at one point in time) priorities they’ve already told you to drop everything else for.
4. “Stop telling me what I don’t want to hear.” 
5. If you don’t want this job, I’ll find someone who does.
6. Hiring For Friends, Not Competencies!
advice_to_mgmt: Perhaps one of the first- and most obvious- signs of a bad manager is that the majority of their employees are unhappy!

headline: Comments about HA

cons: No career and learning opportunities

headline: Administrator
pros: stable work, good friendly atmosphere
cons: slow in making decisions, risk averse
advice_to_mgmt: reduce meetings

headline: Wheels of a Factory
pros:
Decent pay that is paid on years employed rather than incentive based.
No one really cares how well you work or whether you work enough or not- it's a matter of showing up to work and staying through the years.
Working as a team of doctors makes the risk shared when compared with individual practice.
Small groups of individuals work amazingly few productive hours per week on this decent pay.
Still provides amazing subsidized medical service considering the upfront amount that patients have to pay.
cons:
Zero standard in medical training - which can often equate to substandard care. 
Extreme bureaucracy.
Complete lack of respect and concern for the protection of its front-line employees.
Paternalistic management - which can vary between departments.
No tangible incentive to work hard or well towards patient care - as that is not the where the incentives lie. In fact, most incentives encourage as less work as possible - as it often leads to less risk for the doctor, and allows more time for things which will lead to personal advancement. 
In summary - breeds bad work culture as a whole.
advice_to_mgmt: Accountable management.

headline: Overall ok
pros: Stable and decent income, housing and medical benefits

unreceptive to reviews and opinions
Disproportionate resource allocation in unscalable projects
Dispiriting in most teams
Absence of foreplanning by stifling innovation
advice_to_mgmt: Absolutely unsalvageable. Scrap and rebuild. Reform is impossible.
